active_learning.discussion_prompt: Discuss how personnel safety intersects with cybersecurity incidents, using real-world examples like ransomware affecting hospital OT systems or a DDoS attack escalating to physical threats in an ICS environment. Debate whether physical evacuation procedures should be integrated into cyber incident response plans, and justify your position with references to NIST CSF 2.0 and FEMA guidelines.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Emergency Management Procedures under Personnel Safety and Security (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Security And Risk Management > Personnel Security > Special Considerations and Advanced Topics > Personnel Safety and Security > Emergency Management Procedures). Incorporate these pedagogical elements: - Learning Objectives: [Paste the full learning_objectives array here]. - Active Learning: Use concepts from discussion, peer teaching, and problem-solving to inspire question scenarios. - Scaffolding: Distribute flashcards across 4 layers: [Paste scaffolding array]. - Research Context: Key NIST SP 800-61r3 definitions (event, adverse event, incident, response); NIST CSF 2.0 (Govern, Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, Recover); FEMA cyber incident planning & community lifelines; OT/ICS cyber-physical risks. Sources: NIST.SP.800-61r3.pdf, NIST CSF 2.0, FEMA.gov. Generate 25 high-quality flashcards following this exact schema: { "flashcard_id": 1, "front": "Question text with A/B/C/D options", "back": { "answer": "**Correct answer.**", "explanation": "Rationale...", "bloom_level": "APPLY", "scaffolding_layer": "Layer 3", "references": ["NIST SP 800-61r3", "NIST CSF 2.0"] } } Distractors: Follow protocol - plausible misconceptions. Vary formats (MCQ 70%, cloze/short answer 30%). Ensure active recall, no simple lookups. Output as a JSON array of flashcards.
